                      Sixty-five percent of the PwD are performing reminiscence therapy, while 23% stopped doing it due to increased detachment of the PwD (66%), lack of perceived usefulness or PwD inability to attend sessions (25%), lack of material (10%), and lack of time (7%).      \t\tThe remaining ones (12%) never performed reminiscence therapy, as it was prevented by detachment of the PwD (66%), lack of perceived usefulness or PwD not being able to participate (25%), lack of time (8%), and lack of materials (7%).      \t\tWe analyzed whether performing (or not) reminiscence therapy was associated with the overall daily stress, daily stress and daily work due to the PwD, employment, age, and education of caregivers, as well as the age, education and stage of the disease of the PwD.     \t\tThere were no significant relationship for all variables except for caregiver's daily work, PwD's level of education, and disease's stage.     \t\t     \t\t     \t\tThe daily amount of work of the caregiver due to the PwD is statistically significantly different across those that perform (or not) the reminiscence therapy (\u03c7^2(8)=19.694, p=0.009).      \t\tPost-hoc analysis revealed, as expected, that when the amount of daily work with the patient is higher, therapy is performed less often.     \t\tPerforming reminiscence therapy with a moderate amount of daily work with the PwD is significantly more than expected, while those performing therapy with a higher daily work is significantly less than expected.     \t\tFor those that reported a low or moderate amount of work (levels 1 to 3), 67% currently apply reminiscence therapy, 19% already did but stopped, and 14% never did.     \t\tWhen considering a higher amount of work (levels 4 and 5), the ones performing therapy reduced to 57%, while the ones that stopped performing therapy increased to 29%.     \t     \t\t     \t\tThere were a statistically significant relation between performing therapy and the stage of the disease of the PwD (\u03c7^2(6)=54.461, p<.00001).     \t\tPost-hoc analysis suggests that PwD in initial stages of the disease perform therapy often: mild (81%), moderate (74.9%), and severe (47.1%).     \t\tAs the disease progresses, there is an increase in the number of PwD who stop performing therapy: mild (7.1%), moderate (16.3%), and severe (37.1%).     \t\t     \t\tThose performing reminiscence therapy with a moderate stage of dementia are statistically significantly more than expected, while those in a severe stage are statistically significantly less than expected.     \t\tFor those that already performed therapy and the PwD has a moderate stage of dementia are statistically significantly less than expected, while those in a severe stage are statistically significantly more.     \t    There were also a statistically significant relation between performing therapy and the education level of the PwD (\u03c7^2(6)=20.329, p=0.002).     \t\tPost-hoc analysis suggests that those that never performed reminiscence therapy and have a high school degree are significantly more than expected, while the ones with a middle school degree are significantly less.                      \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Session\u2019s Characterization                       For our analysis, we considered answers from caregivers that were performing therapy and those who already performed.     \t\tSessions mainly occur at the home of PwD or relatives (92%) with the attendance of the caregiver (62%) and relatives (62%) besides the PwD, a sessions' frequency per month of either more than 10 times (44%) or 1-2 times (23%), and an average session duration of less than 30 minutes (66%).     \t\tWhen reviewing the past, one can expect that some communication between the PwD and remaining participants takes place.     \t\tIn fact, it occurs: in some cases (38%), a lot (32%), and little (23%).          \t\tIn the course of each session, different multimedia could be used to elicit memories: image, music, video, or combinations among those.     \t\tCaregivers use as stimuli mainly images (55%) or music (37%), and only 18% uses videos; they are usually personal, i.e., multimedia that is related to the PwD and their life: images (88%), videos (73%), and songs (63%).     \t\t     \t\tImages are provided by relatives (81%), the PwD itself (44%), and friends (12%).      \t\tThey are mainly available as printed pictures in physical albums (96%), but they are also stored in the smartphone/tablet gallery (41%), or in the computer (27%).     \t\tMusic is provided by relatives (66%), Internet through music streaming services (46%), and the PwD (32%).     \t\tSongs are usually stored in tapes/CD (57%), streaming services on the Internet (48%), and the computer, smartphone or tablet (45%).     \t\tVideos are provided by relatives (83%), PwD (24%), and friends (21%).     \t\tThey are stored in the computer, smartphone or tablet (71%), and tapes/DVD (43%).      \t\t             \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 PwD Emotional Reactions          \t             When reviewing our memories, it is common to have different emotional reactions - either positive or negative - depending on the memory in question. \t\t\tRegarding the emotional reactions that occur during sessions, caregivers reported that they either perceive what the PwD is feeling (62%) or the PwD is able to describe what he/she is feeling (46%). \t\t\tConsidering the different multimedia used within sessions, images (66%) and music (55%) lead to some kind of positive reaction (e.g., enthusiasm, joy, etc.) from PwD. \t\t\tNegative emotional reactions occurs during sessions (64%). \t\t\t \t\t\tThe main situations in which PwD experience negative emotions are: i) related to cognitive-impairments (58%) - not being able to remember something (e.g., when the memories do not line up with the reality), confusion (e.g., PwD is able to recognize a person in the image but not being able to recall his/her name), and the inability to express what he/she is feeling; ii) autobiographical memories (44%) - remembering (or seeing pictures of) loved ones that have passed away, and bad memories from their lives (e.g., abusive parents or spouse, or a divorce). \t\t\tWhile experiencing negative emotions, PwD's have multiple reactions: behavioral, i.e., getting agitated, aggressive, detached, and anxious (56%), verbal (49%), and emotional, mainly through crying (47%). \t\t\tFollowing, we present some quotes of the informal caregivers that exemplify each of the situations reported.                                                In order to cope with the negative emotional reactions, caregivers adopt different strategies: \t\t    verbal actions toward the PwD (67%), change environment/theme/activity (50.00%), and non-verbal actions toward the PwD (21%). \t\t    We can see in the following quotes that caregivers usually talk with the PwD, trying to calm them down by rationalizing and validating what the PwD are feeling, as well as helping them deal with the triggered memories.  \t\t    However, sometimes, they opt to avoid continuing to talk about specific themes to not worsen the PwD's (or they own) emotional state.                                                \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Life Story Book                       LSB are frequently used as a reminiscence tool to support recollecting autobiographical memories <cit.>. \t\t    They are the result of a life review process performed by the PwD with the support of staff and family members to build a personal biography that acts as a bridge to the past and a connection to the present. \t\t    It can be a very time-consuming task since it may require help from third parties to collect the information, which may not always be feasible or practical. \t\t     \t\t    Only 23% of the caregivers have currently a LSB of the PwD, but the majority of the remaining ones are interested in having one (80%). \t\t    Although we have not collected data to directly answer why most caregivers do not have an LSB of the PwD, as we can see in the following quotes, our open-end questions allow us to hypothesise that it is due to the amount of work (and stress) caregivers already have in their daily live. \t\t     \t\t     \t\t     \t\t    Considering those that already have the LSB or are interested in having one, they mainly prefer to store it the old fashioned way, i.e., physically, such as an album of photos (82%). \t\t    Eighty-two percent of caregivers had (or want) to have help in the process of creating the LSB, and usually they spend (or are willing to spent) up to 10 hours in this process (60%). \t\t    The information is obtained in-person (81%), by e-mail (24%), and through social networks (23%). \t\t    Finally, caregivers indicate that relatives (91%), PwD (62%), friends (57%), and the caregivers themselves (49%) should have access to the LSB.                     \u00a7.\u00a7 Interest in Technological Functionalities               Caregivers are very interested in all the technological functionalities (median of 4 in 5 for each) that may help to revisit older memories from their loved ones or to create an LSB, namely: i) automatically retrieving new images; ii) retrieving life-based images (of the PwD), iii) retrieving interest-based images (e.g., favorite artist, hobbies); iv) adapting current session (based on a negative emotional reaction to an image); v) adapting future sessions (based on the negative emotional reactions that occurred).         \t                                           We further analyzed if the interest in any of the functionalities is associated with currently performing (or  not) the reminiscence therapy, already having a LSB or interest in having one, and finally, the overall daily stress, daily stress and daily work due to the PwD.                                           \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Automatically retrieving new images                      The interest in creating LSB has a significant effect on the level of interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=81.234, p<.00001).                     Post-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference for all pairs: do not want vs want (p<.00001), do not want vs maybe want (p<.00001), and want vs maybe want (p<.00001).                                                        \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Retrieving life-based images                      The interest in creating a LSB has a significant effect on the interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=74.407, p<.00001).                     Post-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference for all pairs: do not want vs want (p<.00001), do not want vs maybe want (p<.00001), and want vs maybe want (p=.001).                     Spearman's rank-order correlation shows a positive correlation between the interest in the functionality and the overall daily stress (r_s(601)=.100, p=.014), and the amount of work with the PwD (r_s(601)=.108, p=.0.008).                                                       \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Retrieving interest-based images                       The interest in creating a LSB has a significant effect on the level of interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=77.558, p<.00001).                     Post-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference for all pairs: do not want vs want (p<.00001), do not want vs maybe want (p<.00001), and want vs maybe want (p=.002).                     A Spearman's rank-order correlation determined that there is a positive correlation between the amount of work of the caregiver with the PwD (r_s(601)=.083, p=.040) and level of interest in the functionality.                                                       \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Adapting current session                       The interest in creating a LSB has a significant effect on the level of interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=50.294, p<.00001).                     Post-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference for two of the pairs: do not want vs want (\u03c7^2(2)=-98.201, p<.00001), and do not want vs maybe want (\u03c7^2(2)=-133.992, p<.00001).                     The Spearman's rank-order correlation shows a positive correlation between the amount of work of caregivers with the PwD (r_s(601)=.099, p=.015) and level of interest in the functionality.                                                       \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Adapting future sessions                      The interest in creating a LSB has a significant effect on the level of interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=38.561, p<.00001).                     A pairwise post-hoc Dunn test with Bonferroni adjustments was significant for the pairs: do not want vs want (p<.00001), and do not want vs maybe want (p<.00001).               Conducting reminiscence therapy sessions does not seem to be associated with the level of interest in any of the technological functionalities presented.         Caregivers that are not interested in creating an LSB are less interested in the aforementioned technological functionalities than those interested in having one, and in the majority, those that want to create an LSB are slightly more interested than those that might want to create the LSB.         With a higher overall stress of the caregiver, the interest in Retrieving life-based images appears to increase.         A higher amount of work of the caregiver with the PwD increases the interest in Retrieving life-based images, Retrieving interest-based images, and Adapting current session.                          \u00a7 SURVEY 2           In this section, we present our results regarding sample characteristics (of caregivers), how reminiscence sessions are conducted, and how the results of reminiscence sessions (and overall health of the PwD) are evaluated in follow-up medical appointments.     Finally, we assess the level of interest in technological functionalities to help in the care of PwD (management of patients, information related to sessions carried out, management of the multimedia material to be used in sessions, and which help tools should be available), and how this interest differs between formal and informal caregivers.          The privacy of the information exchanged is very important, especially when other people are involved.     Beyond ethical issues, the non-guarantee of privacy may even hinder the embrace of new technology from caregivers.     As such, we also address how comfortable caregivers would be inserting personal content on technological solutions (assuming that only authorized people would be able to consult the data).               \u00a7.\u00a7 Informal Caregivers               Following, we detail the results obtained for the informal caregivers.         Where relevant, we compare the results with those of the previous study.                  \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Sample Characteristics                   A total of 102 informal caregivers worldwide answered our survey.             Ninety two percent were female, younger than 70 y-o (90%), completed higher education (65%), and have mild to moderate visual impairments (58%).             They usually take care of one PwD (87%) that is either they spouse (39%) or a relative (53%).              Usually, the PwD they look after are in a state that is perceived as severe (61%).             Finally, the average number of hours in the day that the caregiver spend caring for the PwD is above 8 (equivalent to a full-time job)  (60%).                              Most caregivers are familiar with technology: they use mobile phones five to six days a week, and computers/tablet/iPad three to four days a week.                          \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Reminiscence Therapy                       Forty-one percent of caregivers perform reminiscence therapy with the PwD they care for.             The number of sessions conducted per month is either more than 10 (43%), 3-4 (21%) or 1-2 (21%).             Sessions occur mainly at home (88%), with an average duration of less than 30 minutes (74%).                          It is worth noting that the performance of the reminiscence sessions decreased compared to the previous survey (about 20%).             We believe it is due to the fact that informal caregivers are increasingly overburdened and subject to high levels of stress, which may have been exacerbated by the pandemic situation experienced at the time of data collection.             Moreover, we believe the existing confinements due to the pandemic increased the isolation of the PwD, decreasing the contact between them and their relatives, both at home and in the institutions, which conditioned the realization of the therapy, and made it difficult to gather materials for the sessions.                          Images (88%), music (67%), and videos (43%) are used as triggers to stimulate the memory of PwD, and are mostly personal (95%).             They are related to the relatives of the PwD (93%), jobs and places the person visited (62% each), places where the person lived (57%), pets (52%), vehicles they had (33%), among others (23%), such as parties/happy moments, favorite activities, childhood memories, food, and dance.             Such materials are provided mainly by relatives of the PwD (81%), friends (29%), the person itself (21%), or  gathered from the internet (40%).             Caregivers would like to use other multimedia more often: videos (52%), images (38%), and music/text (29% each).             Images and music usually elicit positive emotional reactions in the PwD (71% each), while images (26%) and videos/text (24% each) usually elicit negative emotional reactions.                                                Caregivers update the material on a daily (29%),  monthly (26%), or weekly (17%) basis.             The main reasons that keep them from updating the material more often are: the detachment of the PwD (50%), lack of time (30%), and lack of materials (20%).             Seventeen percent of the caregivers never update the material.             We also believe that the caregivers' overload and stress, as well as the pandemic situation has affected not only the completion of the reminiscence therapy, but its quality when performed since caregivers did not have the time or materials available to diversify the following sessions.                           Regarding the information collected by the caregivers from each session, they register the materials that elicited positive emotional reactions (57%), materials that helped to recall past memories (55%), the emotional state of the PwD both before and after the session (38% each), and the material that elicited negative emotional reactions (19%).             There are no other types of information that caregivers would like to include in their notes about each session.             Fourteen percent of caregivers do not collect any information.                          \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Follow-up Medical Appointments                                             Thirty-seven percent of surveyed caregivers take the PwD to follow-up medical appointment, in particular they accompany the PwD on a daily (32%) or weekly (16%) basis.             Thirty-four percent of caregivers reported that the PwD do not go to follow-up appointments despite having indicated they did in the previous question.              We believe this is due to not having immediately understood the concept of follow-up appointment.             Caregivers report they do not attend the appointments more often due to lack of time.                      The emotional reactions and emotional well-being of the PwD is usually analysed during the appointments (64% each), as well as the results from previous reminiscence sessions (48%).             Additionally, caregivers perform other follow-up of PwD besides medical consultations or reminiscence therapy, such as cognitive stimulation, walks in places PwD used to enjoy, art therapy, shopping, visiting places where PwD lived, psychomotricity activities, daily contact with the PwD, and gathering relevant information through collaborators/health team.                          \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Interest in Technological Functionalities                       Thirty three percent of caregivers take advantage of technology to take care of PwD, such as audio books, blue laser light, camera, computer, Internet, phone, radio, tablet/iPad, television, and videos.                              Considering the different technological functionalities for the management and adaptation of reminiscence sessions, informal caregivers have a moderate interest for the most part (median of 3 in 5 for each).             This apparent decrease in interest (compared to our previous survey) will be addressed in the follow-up interviews.             The actual performance of the reminiscence therapy has not proved to be statistically significant for any of the functionalities in question.                              Caregivers indicate that they are comfortable introducing personal content into a technological system, as long as the system guarantees maximum privacy and security.                      \u00a7.\u00a7 Formal Caregivers               Following, we present our results regarding formal caregivers.                      \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Sample Characteristics                       A total of 34 formal caregivers answered our survey.              They were mostly female (85%), younger than 50 y-o (64%), completed higher education (85%), and do not have any visual impairments (65%).             They take care of more than seven PwD (76%), and at least one of the PwD is in a severe state of dementia (74%).                          The majority of caregivers are familiar with technology: they use mobile phones daily, and computers/tablet/iPad six days a week.                              \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Reminiscence Therapy                       Formal caregivers perform reminiscence therapy sessions more often than the informal ones (68% vs 41%).             They usually conduct the sessions 3-4 (39%) or 5-10 (30%) times per month.             Sessions occur mainly at the institution (74%) but in the house of the PwD as well (35%), with an average duration of 30-60 minutes (65%) or less than 30 minutes (30%).                          Images (95%), music (87%), videos (57%), and text (48%) are used to stimulate memories, and are both personal (87%) and general (83%).                          Caregivers would like to use video (57%), text (48%), images (43%), music (39%), and other materials (such as objects, arts' material, games, daily activities, and visits to places of interest) more often.                          The materials used are related to places where the person lived (96%), PwD's relatives (87%), places PwD visited (83%), jobs of the PwD (78%), pets (70%), and vehicles they had (43%).             Caregivers also report that they like to use material related to other topics such as habits, hobbies, favorite food, musicians, television shows, movies and actors, important dates, past and present objects, sports, or plants.             Materials are obtained through the Internet (87%), or provided by PwD's relatives (74%), the PwD (57%), or friends (43%).             The material is updated in a monthly (26%), weekly (22%), daily or fortnightly (17% each) basis.             They do not update it more often due to lack of time (100%), lack of perceived usefulness for the PwD (50%), and lack of materials or need to repeat the same activities (25% each).                              Caregivers collect information about the emotional state of the PwD after sessions (87%), material that helped to recall past memories or elicited positive emotional reactions (83% each), material that elicited negative emotional reactions (70%), PwD's emotional state before sessions (65%), and duration of each session (48%).             Moreover, they also collect the degree of involvement and interest of PwD, level of communication, dynamics with caregiver or the group, PwD answers during the session, as well as periodic assessments of cognitive functions.                          Finally, they show interest in being able to collect the intensity level of emotional reactions (positive and negative) to specific stimuli, record permission for assessments, how the PwD was during the session (refusals, non-verbal language, behavior, relationship with therapist, initiative in contact), and in-session responses that might be relevant in future sessions.                      \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Follow-up Medical Appointments                       Fifty-three percent of the formal caregivers conduct follow-up medical appointments with the PwD on a daily (28%) or weekly (28%) basis.             Caregivers report they do not conduct appointments more often because of the costs associated.                              The emotional well-being of the PwD is almost always evaluated at the appointments (93%), followed by the PwD's emotional reactions (87%), and the results from previous reminiscence sessions (67%).             Other follow-up activities with the PwD are conducted (49%), in particular, cognitive stimulation, movement sessions, sensory stimulation sessions, hygiene/food care, caregiver support with family members and joint sessions (PwD and family), psychotherapy, and games.                                \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Interest in Technological Functionalities                           Sixty-five percent of caregivers already use technology to help them in the care of the PwD, in particular, the CogWeb application <cit.>, computer, images, music, mobile phones, overhead projector, snoezelen (multi sensory) room, tablet, and videos.                          They are interested in all the technological functionalities, in particular, they are very interested in those related to the adaptation and personalization of sessions.             Their interest is much higher than that of the informal caregivers, which we believe is due to the fact that most of the informal caregivers only take care of one person and do not need to manage several PwD at the same time.             Such difference in the interest across the type of caregivers is statistically significant for all functionalities:                          Management of PwD:         \t             \t   \t       * Creating reminders ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t   \t       * Notifying other caregivers ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t   \t       * Sharing care with others ( RPLUS MATCH )                          \tReminiscence sessions:         \t             \t           * Automatically adapting the session content based on the biographical information of the PwD ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Automatically adapting the session content based on the emotional reactions of the PwD to the materials presented ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Consulting the materials used in each therapy session ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Consulting the history of caregiver's sessions ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Consulting the history of the PwD's sessions even if performed by others ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t             \t            \tMaterial used in the therapy sessions:         \t             \t           * Inserting new material ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Inserting material topics ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Creating a favorites section in each patient's material ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t                 Help tools for the users:         \t             \t           * Email/Telephone (U=1276.50, p=.018", "statisticType": "mwutest", "record": {"pval": ".018", "U": "1276.50", "r": null, "z": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

that those that never performed reminiscence therapy and have a high school degree are significantly more than expected, while the ones with a middle school degree are significantly less.                      \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Session\u2019s Characterization                       For our analysis, we considered answers from caregivers that were performing therapy and those who already performed.     \t\tSessions mainly occur at the home of PwD or relatives (92%) with the attendance of the caregiver (62%) and relatives (62%) besides the PwD, a sessions' frequency per month of either more than 10 times (44%) or 1-2 times (23%), and an average session duration of less than 30 minutes (66%).     \t\tWhen reviewing the past, one can expect that some communication between the PwD and remaining participants takes place.     \t\tIn fact, it occurs: in some cases (38%), a lot (32%), and little (23%).          \t\tIn the course of each session, different multimedia could be used to elicit memories: image, music, video, or combinations among those.     \t\tCaregivers use as stimuli mainly images (55%) or music (37%), and only 18% uses videos; they are usually personal, i.e., multimedia that is related to the PwD and their life: images (88%), videos (73%), and songs (63%).     \t\t     \t\tImages are provided by relatives (81%), the PwD itself (44%), and friends (12%).      \t\tThey are mainly available as printed pictures in physical albums (96%), but they are also stored in the smartphone/tablet gallery (41%), or in the computer (27%).     \t\tMusic is provided by relatives (66%), Internet through music streaming services (46%), and the PwD (32%).     \t\tSongs are usually stored in tapes/CD (57%), streaming services on the Internet (48%), and the computer, smartphone or tablet (45%).     \t\tVideos are provided by relatives (83%), PwD (24%), and friends (21%).     \t\tThey are stored in the computer, smartphone or tablet (71%), and tapes/DVD (43%).      \t\t             \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 PwD Emotional Reactions          \t             When reviewing our memories, it is common to have different emotional reactions - either positive or negative - depending on the memory in question. \t\t\tRegarding the emotional reactions that occur during sessions, caregivers reported that they either perceive what the PwD is feeling (62%) or the PwD is able to describe what he/she is feeling (46%). \t\t\tConsidering the different multimedia used within sessions, images (66%) and music (55%) lead to some kind of positive reaction (e.g., enthusiasm, joy, etc.) from PwD. \t\t\tNegative emotional reactions occurs during sessions (64%). \t\t\t \t\t\tThe main situations in which PwD experience negative emotions are: i) related to cognitive-impairments (58%) - not being able to remember something (e.g., when the memories do not line up with the reality), confusion (e.g., PwD is able to recognize a person in the image but not being able to recall his/her name), and the inability to express what he/she is feeling; ii) autobiographical memories (44%) - remembering (or seeing pictures of) loved ones that have passed away, and bad memories from their lives (e.g., abusive parents or spouse, or a divorce). \t\t\tWhile experiencing negative emotions, PwD's have multiple reactions: behavioral, i.e., getting agitated, aggressive, detached, and anxious (56%), verbal (49%), and emotional, mainly through crying (47%). \t\t\tFollowing, we present some quotes of the informal caregivers that exemplify each of the situations reported.                                                In order to cope with the negative emotional reactions, caregivers adopt different strategies: \t\t    verbal actions toward the PwD (67%), change environment/theme/activity (50.00%), and non-verbal actions toward the PwD (21%). \t\t    We can see in the following quotes that caregivers usually talk with the PwD, trying to calm them down by rationalizing and validating what the PwD are feeling, as well as helping them deal with the triggered memories.  \t\t    However, sometimes, they opt to avoid continuing to talk about specific themes to not worsen the PwD's (or they own) emotional state.                                                \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Life Story Book                       LSB are frequently used as a reminiscence tool to support recollecting autobiographical memories <cit.>. \t\t    They are the result of a life review process performed by the PwD with the support of staff and family members to build a personal biography that acts as a bridge to the past and a connection to the present. \t\t    It can be a very time-consuming task since it may require help from third parties to collect the information, which may not always be feasible or practical. \t\t     \t\t    Only 23% of the caregivers have currently a LSB of the PwD, but the majority of the remaining ones are interested in having one (80%). \t\t    Although we have not collected data to directly answer why most caregivers do not have an LSB of the PwD, as we can see in the following quotes, our open-end questions allow us to hypothesise that it is due to the amount of work (and stress) caregivers already have in their daily live. \t\t     \t\t     \t\t     \t\t    Considering those that already have the LSB or are interested in having one, they mainly prefer to store it the old fashioned way, i.e., physically, such as an album of photos (82%). \t\t    Eighty-two percent of caregivers had (or want) to have help in the process of creating the LSB, and usually they spend (or are willing to spent) up to 10 hours in this process (60%). \t\t    The information is obtained in-person (81%), by e-mail (24%), and through social networks (23%). \t\t    Finally, caregivers indicate that relatives (91%), PwD (62%), friends (57%), and the caregivers themselves (49%) should have access to the LSB.                     \u00a7.\u00a7 Interest in Technological Functionalities               Caregivers are very interested in all the technological functionalities (median of 4 in 5 for each) that may help to revisit older memories from their loved ones or to create an LSB, namely: i) automatically retrieving new images; ii) retrieving life-based images (of the PwD), iii) retrieving interest-based images (e.g., favorite artist, hobbies); iv) adapting current session (based on a negative emotional reaction to an image); v) adapting future sessions (based on the negative emotional reactions that occurred).         \t                                           We further analyzed if the interest in any of the functionalities is associated with currently performing (or  not) the reminiscence therapy, already having a LSB or interest in having one, and finally, the overall daily stress, daily stress and daily work due to the PwD.                                           \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Automatically retrieving new images                      The interest in creating LSB has a significant effect on the level of interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=81.234, p<.00001).                     Post-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference for all pairs: do not want vs want (p<.00001), do not want vs maybe want (p<.00001), and want vs maybe want (p<.00001).                                                        \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Retrieving life-based images                      The interest in creating a LSB has a significant effect on the interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=74.407, p<.00001).                     Post-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference for all pairs: do not want vs want (p<.00001), do not want vs maybe want (p<.00001), and want vs maybe want (p=.001).                     Spearman's rank-order correlation shows a positive correlation between the interest in the functionality and the overall daily stress (r_s(601)=.100, p=.014), and the amount of work with the PwD (r_s(601)=.108, p=.0.008).                                                       \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Retrieving interest-based images                       The interest in creating a LSB has a significant effect on the level of interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=77.558, p<.00001).                     Post-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference for all pairs: do not want vs want (p<.00001), do not want vs maybe want (p<.00001), and want vs maybe want (p=.002).                     A Spearman's rank-order correlation determined that there is a positive correlation between the amount of work of the caregiver with the PwD (r_s(601)=.083, p=.040) and level of interest in the functionality.                                                       \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Adapting current session                       The interest in creating a LSB has a significant effect on the level of interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=50.294, p<.00001).                     Post-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference for two of the pairs: do not want vs want (\u03c7^2(2)=-98.201, p<.00001), and do not want vs maybe want (\u03c7^2(2)=-133.992, p<.00001).                     The Spearman's rank-order correlation shows a positive correlation between the amount of work of caregivers with the PwD (r_s(601)=.099, p=.015) and level of interest in the functionality.                                                       \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Adapting future sessions                      The interest in creating a LSB has a significant effect on the level of interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=38.561, p<.00001).                     A pairwise post-hoc Dunn test with Bonferroni adjustments was significant for the pairs: do not want vs want (p<.00001), and do not want vs maybe want (p<.00001).               Conducting reminiscence therapy sessions does not seem to be associated with the level of interest in any of the technological functionalities presented.         Caregivers that are not interested in creating an LSB are less interested in the aforementioned technological functionalities than those interested in having one, and in the majority, those that want to create an LSB are slightly more interested than those that might want to create the LSB.         With a higher overall stress of the caregiver, the interest in Retrieving life-based images appears to increase.         A higher amount of work of the caregiver with the PwD increases the interest in Retrieving life-based images, Retrieving interest-based images, and Adapting current session.                          \u00a7 SURVEY 2           In this section, we present our results regarding sample characteristics (of caregivers), how reminiscence sessions are conducted, and how the results of reminiscence sessions (and overall health of the PwD) are evaluated in follow-up medical appointments.     Finally, we assess the level of interest in technological functionalities to help in the care of PwD (management of patients, information related to sessions carried out, management of the multimedia material to be used in sessions, and which help tools should be available), and how this interest differs between formal and informal caregivers.          The privacy of the information exchanged is very important, especially when other people are involved.     Beyond ethical issues, the non-guarantee of privacy may even hinder the embrace of new technology from caregivers.     As such, we also address how comfortable caregivers would be inserting personal content on technological solutions (assuming that only authorized people would be able to consult the data).               \u00a7.\u00a7 Informal Caregivers               Following, we detail the results obtained for the informal caregivers.         Where relevant, we compare the results with those of the previous study.                  \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Sample Characteristics                   A total of 102 informal caregivers worldwide answered our survey.             Ninety two percent were female, younger than 70 y-o (90%), completed higher education (65%), and have mild to moderate visual impairments (58%).             They usually take care of one PwD (87%) that is either they spouse (39%) or a relative (53%).              Usually, the PwD they look after are in a state that is perceived as severe (61%).             Finally, the average number of hours in the day that the caregiver spend caring for the PwD is above 8 (equivalent to a full-time job)  (60%).                              Most caregivers are familiar with technology: they use mobile phones five to six days a week, and computers/tablet/iPad three to four days a week.                          \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Reminiscence Therapy                       Forty-one percent of caregivers perform reminiscence therapy with the PwD they care for.             The number of sessions conducted per month is either more than 10 (43%), 3-4 (21%) or 1-2 (21%).             Sessions occur mainly at home (88%), with an average duration of less than 30 minutes (74%).                          It is worth noting that the performance of the reminiscence sessions decreased compared to the previous survey (about 20%).             We believe it is due to the fact that informal caregivers are increasingly overburdened and subject to high levels of stress, which may have been exacerbated by the pandemic situation experienced at the time of data collection.             Moreover, we believe the existing confinements due to the pandemic increased the isolation of the PwD, decreasing the contact between them and their relatives, both at home and in the institutions, which conditioned the realization of the therapy, and made it difficult to gather materials for the sessions.                          Images (88%), music (67%), and videos (43%) are used as triggers to stimulate the memory of PwD, and are mostly personal (95%).             They are related to the relatives of the PwD (93%), jobs and places the person visited (62% each), places where the person lived (57%), pets (52%), vehicles they had (33%), among others (23%), such as parties/happy moments, favorite activities, childhood memories, food, and dance.             Such materials are provided mainly by relatives of the PwD (81%), friends (29%), the person itself (21%), or  gathered from the internet (40%).             Caregivers would like to use other multimedia more often: videos (52%), images (38%), and music/text (29% each).             Images and music usually elicit positive emotional reactions in the PwD (71% each), while images (26%) and videos/text (24% each) usually elicit negative emotional reactions.                                                Caregivers update the material on a daily (29%),  monthly (26%), or weekly (17%) basis.             The main reasons that keep them from updating the material more often are: the detachment of the PwD (50%), lack of time (30%), and lack of materials (20%).             Seventeen percent of the caregivers never update the material.             We also believe that the caregivers' overload and stress, as well as the pandemic situation has affected not only the completion of the reminiscence therapy, but its quality when performed since caregivers did not have the time or materials available to diversify the following sessions.                           Regarding the information collected by the caregivers from each session, they register the materials that elicited positive emotional reactions (57%), materials that helped to recall past memories (55%), the emotional state of the PwD both before and after the session (38% each), and the material that elicited negative emotional reactions (19%).             There are no other types of information that caregivers would like to include in their notes about each session.             Fourteen percent of caregivers do not collect any information.                          \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Follow-up Medical Appointments                                             Thirty-seven percent of surveyed caregivers take the PwD to follow-up medical appointment, in particular they accompany the PwD on a daily (32%) or weekly (16%) basis.             Thirty-four percent of caregivers reported that the PwD do not go to follow-up appointments despite having indicated they did in the previous question.              We believe this is due to not having immediately understood the concept of follow-up appointment.             Caregivers report they do not attend the appointments more often due to lack of time.                      The emotional reactions and emotional well-being of the PwD is usually analysed during the appointments (64% each), as well as the results from previous reminiscence sessions (48%).             Additionally, caregivers perform other follow-up of PwD besides medical consultations or reminiscence therapy, such as cognitive stimulation, walks in places PwD used to enjoy, art therapy, shopping, visiting places where PwD lived, psychomotricity activities, daily contact with the PwD, and gathering relevant information through collaborators/health team.                          \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Interest in Technological Functionalities                       Thirty three percent of caregivers take advantage of technology to take care of PwD, such as audio books, blue laser light, camera, computer, Internet, phone, radio, tablet/iPad, television, and videos.                              Considering the different technological functionalities for the management and adaptation of reminiscence sessions, informal caregivers have a moderate interest for the most part (median of 3 in 5 for each).             This apparent decrease in interest (compared to our previous survey) will be addressed in the follow-up interviews.             The actual performance of the reminiscence therapy has not proved to be statistically significant for any of the functionalities in question.                              Caregivers indicate that they are comfortable introducing personal content into a technological system, as long as the system guarantees maximum privacy and security.                      \u00a7.\u00a7 Formal Caregivers               Following, we present our results regarding formal caregivers.                      \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Sample Characteristics                       A total of 34 formal caregivers answered our survey.              They were mostly female (85%), younger than 50 y-o (64%), completed higher education (85%), and do not have any visual impairments (65%).             They take care of more than seven PwD (76%), and at least one of the PwD is in a severe state of dementia (74%).                          The majority of caregivers are familiar with technology: they use mobile phones daily, and computers/tablet/iPad six days a week.                              \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Reminiscence Therapy                       Formal caregivers perform reminiscence therapy sessions more often than the informal ones (68% vs 41%).             They usually conduct the sessions 3-4 (39%) or 5-10 (30%) times per month.             Sessions occur mainly at the institution (74%) but in the house of the PwD as well (35%), with an average duration of 30-60 minutes (65%) or less than 30 minutes (30%).                          Images (95%), music (87%), videos (57%), and text (48%) are used to stimulate memories, and are both personal (87%) and general (83%).                          Caregivers would like to use video (57%), text (48%), images (43%), music (39%), and other materials (such as objects, arts' material, games, daily activities, and visits to places of interest) more often.                          The materials used are related to places where the person lived (96%), PwD's relatives (87%), places PwD visited (83%), jobs of the PwD (78%), pets (70%), and vehicles they had (43%).             Caregivers also report that they like to use material related to other topics such as habits, hobbies, favorite food, musicians, television shows, movies and actors, important dates, past and present objects, sports, or plants.             Materials are obtained through the Internet (87%), or provided by PwD's relatives (74%), the PwD (57%), or friends (43%).             The material is updated in a monthly (26%), weekly (22%), daily or fortnightly (17% each) basis.             They do not update it more often due to lack of time (100%), lack of perceived usefulness for the PwD (50%), and lack of materials or need to repeat the same activities (25% each).                              Caregivers collect information about the emotional state of the PwD after sessions (87%), material that helped to recall past memories or elicited positive emotional reactions (83% each), material that elicited negative emotional reactions (70%), PwD's emotional state before sessions (65%), and duration of each session (48%).             Moreover, they also collect the degree of involvement and interest of PwD, level of communication, dynamics with caregiver or the group, PwD answers during the session, as well as periodic assessments of cognitive functions.                          Finally, they show interest in being able to collect the intensity level of emotional reactions (positive and negative) to specific stimuli, record permission for assessments, how the PwD was during the session (refusals, non-verbal language, behavior, relationship with therapist, initiative in contact), and in-session responses that might be relevant in future sessions.                      \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Follow-up Medical Appointments                       Fifty-three percent of the formal caregivers conduct follow-up medical appointments with the PwD on a daily (28%) or weekly (28%) basis.             Caregivers report they do not conduct appointments more often because of the costs associated.                              The emotional well-being of the PwD is almost always evaluated at the appointments (93%), followed by the PwD's emotional reactions (87%), and the results from previous reminiscence sessions (67%).             Other follow-up activities with the PwD are conducted (49%), in particular, cognitive stimulation, movement sessions, sensory stimulation sessions, hygiene/food care, caregiver support with family members and joint sessions (PwD and family), psychotherapy, and games.                                \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Interest in Technological Functionalities                           Sixty-five percent of caregivers already use technology to help them in the care of the PwD, in particular, the CogWeb application <cit.>, computer, images, music, mobile phones, overhead projector, snoezelen (multi sensory) room, tablet, and videos.                          They are interested in all the technological functionalities, in particular, they are very interested in those related to the adaptation and personalization of sessions.             Their interest is much higher than that of the informal caregivers, which we believe is due to the fact that most of the informal caregivers only take care of one person and do not need to manage several PwD at the same time.             Such difference in the interest across the type of caregivers is statistically significant for all functionalities:                          Management of PwD:         \t             \t   \t       * Creating reminders ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t   \t       * Notifying other caregivers ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t   \t       * Sharing care with others ( RPLUS MATCH )                          \tReminiscence sessions:         \t             \t           * Automatically adapting the session content based on the biographical information of the PwD ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Automatically adapting the session content based on the emotional reactions of the PwD to the materials presented ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Consulting the materials used in each therapy session ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Consulting the history of caregiver's sessions ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Consulting the history of the PwD's sessions even if performed by others ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t             \t            \tMaterial used in the therapy sessions:         \t             \t           * Inserting new material ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Inserting material topics ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Creating a favorites section in each patient's material ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t                 Help tools for the users:         \t             \t           * Email/Telephone ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Help within application (U=1168.50, p=.004", "statisticType": "mwutest", "record": {"pval": ".004", "U": "1168.50", "r": null, "z": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

   \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 PwD Emotional Reactions          \t             When reviewing our memories, it is common to have different emotional reactions - either positive or negative - depending on the memory in question. \t\t\tRegarding the emotional reactions that occur during sessions, caregivers reported that they either perceive what the PwD is feeling (62%) or the PwD is able to describe what he/she is feeling (46%). \t\t\tConsidering the different multimedia used within sessions, images (66%) and music (55%) lead to some kind of positive reaction (e.g., enthusiasm, joy, etc.) from PwD. \t\t\tNegative emotional reactions occurs during sessions (64%). \t\t\t \t\t\tThe main situations in which PwD experience negative emotions are: i) related to cognitive-impairments (58%) - not being able to remember something (e.g., when the memories do not line up with the reality), confusion (e.g., PwD is able to recognize a person in the image but not being able to recall his/her name), and the inability to express what he/she is feeling; ii) autobiographical memories (44%) - remembering (or seeing pictures of) loved ones that have passed away, and bad memories from their lives (e.g., abusive parents or spouse, or a divorce). \t\t\tWhile experiencing negative emotions, PwD's have multiple reactions: behavioral, i.e., getting agitated, aggressive, detached, and anxious (56%), verbal (49%), and emotional, mainly through crying (47%). \t\t\tFollowing, we present some quotes of the informal caregivers that exemplify each of the situations reported.                                                In order to cope with the negative emotional reactions, caregivers adopt different strategies: \t\t    verbal actions toward the PwD (67%), change environment/theme/activity (50.00%), and non-verbal actions toward the PwD (21%). \t\t    We can see in the following quotes that caregivers usually talk with the PwD, trying to calm them down by rationalizing and validating what the PwD are feeling, as well as helping them deal with the triggered memories.  \t\t    However, sometimes, they opt to avoid continuing to talk about specific themes to not worsen the PwD's (or they own) emotional state.                                                \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Life Story Book                       LSB are frequently used as a reminiscence tool to support recollecting autobiographical memories <cit.>. \t\t    They are the result of a life review process performed by the PwD with the support of staff and family members to build a personal biography that acts as a bridge to the past and a connection to the present. \t\t    It can be a very time-consuming task since it may require help from third parties to collect the information, which may not always be feasible or practical. \t\t     \t\t    Only 23% of the caregivers have currently a LSB of the PwD, but the majority of the remaining ones are interested in having one (80%). \t\t    Although we have not collected data to directly answer why most caregivers do not have an LSB of the PwD, as we can see in the following quotes, our open-end questions allow us to hypothesise that it is due to the amount of work (and stress) caregivers already have in their daily live. \t\t     \t\t     \t\t     \t\t    Considering those that already have the LSB or are interested in having one, they mainly prefer to store it the old fashioned way, i.e., physically, such as an album of photos (82%). \t\t    Eighty-two percent of caregivers had (or want) to have help in the process of creating the LSB, and usually they spend (or are willing to spent) up to 10 hours in this process (60%). \t\t    The information is obtained in-person (81%), by e-mail (24%), and through social networks (23%). \t\t    Finally, caregivers indicate that relatives (91%), PwD (62%), friends (57%), and the caregivers themselves (49%) should have access to the LSB.                     \u00a7.\u00a7 Interest in Technological Functionalities               Caregivers are very interested in all the technological functionalities (median of 4 in 5 for each) that may help to revisit older memories from their loved ones or to create an LSB, namely: i) automatically retrieving new images; ii) retrieving life-based images (of the PwD), iii) retrieving interest-based images (e.g., favorite artist, hobbies); iv) adapting current session (based on a negative emotional reaction to an image); v) adapting future sessions (based on the negative emotional reactions that occurred).         \t                                           We further analyzed if the interest in any of the functionalities is associated with currently performing (or  not) the reminiscence therapy, already having a LSB or interest in having one, and finally, the overall daily stress, daily stress and daily work due to the PwD.                                           \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Automatically retrieving new images                      The interest in creating LSB has a significant effect on the level of interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=81.234, p<.00001).                     Post-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference for all pairs: do not want vs want (p<.00001), do not want vs maybe want (p<.00001), and want vs maybe want (p<.00001).                                                        \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Retrieving life-based images                      The interest in creating a LSB has a significant effect on the interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=74.407, p<.00001).                     Post-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference for all pairs: do not want vs want (p<.00001), do not want vs maybe want (p<.00001), and want vs maybe want (p=.001).                     Spearman's rank-order correlation shows a positive correlation between the interest in the functionality and the overall daily stress (r_s(601)=.100, p=.014), and the amount of work with the PwD (r_s(601)=.108, p=.0.008).                                                       \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Retrieving interest-based images                       The interest in creating a LSB has a significant effect on the level of interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=77.558, p<.00001).                     Post-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference for all pairs: do not want vs want (p<.00001), do not want vs maybe want (p<.00001), and want vs maybe want (p=.002).                     A Spearman's rank-order correlation determined that there is a positive correlation between the amount of work of the caregiver with the PwD (r_s(601)=.083, p=.040) and level of interest in the functionality.                                                       \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Adapting current session                       The interest in creating a LSB has a significant effect on the level of interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=50.294, p<.00001).                     Post-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference for two of the pairs: do not want vs want (\u03c7^2(2)=-98.201, p<.00001), and do not want vs maybe want (\u03c7^2(2)=-133.992, p<.00001).                     The Spearman's rank-order correlation shows a positive correlation between the amount of work of caregivers with the PwD (r_s(601)=.099, p=.015) and level of interest in the functionality.                                                       \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Adapting future sessions                      The interest in creating a LSB has a significant effect on the level of interest in this functionality (\u03c7^2(2)=38.561, p<.00001).                     A pairwise post-hoc Dunn test with Bonferroni adjustments was significant for the pairs: do not want vs want (p<.00001), and do not want vs maybe want (p<.00001).               Conducting reminiscence therapy sessions does not seem to be associated with the level of interest in any of the technological functionalities presented.         Caregivers that are not interested in creating an LSB are less interested in the aforementioned technological functionalities than those interested in having one, and in the majority, those that want to create an LSB are slightly more interested than those that might want to create the LSB.         With a higher overall stress of the caregiver, the interest in Retrieving life-based images appears to increase.         A higher amount of work of the caregiver with the PwD increases the interest in Retrieving life-based images, Retrieving interest-based images, and Adapting current session.                          \u00a7 SURVEY 2           In this section, we present our results regarding sample characteristics (of caregivers), how reminiscence sessions are conducted, and how the results of reminiscence sessions (and overall health of the PwD) are evaluated in follow-up medical appointments.     Finally, we assess the level of interest in technological functionalities to help in the care of PwD (management of patients, information related to sessions carried out, management of the multimedia material to be used in sessions, and which help tools should be available), and how this interest differs between formal and informal caregivers.          The privacy of the information exchanged is very important, especially when other people are involved.     Beyond ethical issues, the non-guarantee of privacy may even hinder the embrace of new technology from caregivers.     As such, we also address how comfortable caregivers would be inserting personal content on technological solutions (assuming that only authorized people would be able to consult the data).               \u00a7.\u00a7 Informal Caregivers               Following, we detail the results obtained for the informal caregivers.         Where relevant, we compare the results with those of the previous study.                  \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Sample Characteristics                   A total of 102 informal caregivers worldwide answered our survey.             Ninety two percent were female, younger than 70 y-o (90%), completed higher education (65%), and have mild to moderate visual impairments (58%).             They usually take care of one PwD (87%) that is either they spouse (39%) or a relative (53%).              Usually, the PwD they look after are in a state that is perceived as severe (61%).             Finally, the average number of hours in the day that the caregiver spend caring for the PwD is above 8 (equivalent to a full-time job)  (60%).                              Most caregivers are familiar with technology: they use mobile phones five to six days a week, and computers/tablet/iPad three to four days a week.                          \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Reminiscence Therapy                       Forty-one percent of caregivers perform reminiscence therapy with the PwD they care for.             The number of sessions conducted per month is either more than 10 (43%), 3-4 (21%) or 1-2 (21%).             Sessions occur mainly at home (88%), with an average duration of less than 30 minutes (74%).                          It is worth noting that the performance of the reminiscence sessions decreased compared to the previous survey (about 20%).             We believe it is due to the fact that informal caregivers are increasingly overburdened and subject to high levels of stress, which may have been exacerbated by the pandemic situation experienced at the time of data collection.             Moreover, we believe the existing confinements due to the pandemic increased the isolation of the PwD, decreasing the contact between them and their relatives, both at home and in the institutions, which conditioned the realization of the therapy, and made it difficult to gather materials for the sessions.                          Images (88%), music (67%), and videos (43%) are used as triggers to stimulate the memory of PwD, and are mostly personal (95%).             They are related to the relatives of the PwD (93%), jobs and places the person visited (62% each), places where the person lived (57%), pets (52%), vehicles they had (33%), among others (23%), such as parties/happy moments, favorite activities, childhood memories, food, and dance.             Such materials are provided mainly by relatives of the PwD (81%), friends (29%), the person itself (21%), or  gathered from the internet (40%).             Caregivers would like to use other multimedia more often: videos (52%), images (38%), and music/text (29% each).             Images and music usually elicit positive emotional reactions in the PwD (71% each), while images (26%) and videos/text (24% each) usually elicit negative emotional reactions.                                                Caregivers update the material on a daily (29%),  monthly (26%), or weekly (17%) basis.             The main reasons that keep them from updating the material more often are: the detachment of the PwD (50%), lack of time (30%), and lack of materials (20%).             Seventeen percent of the caregivers never update the material.             We also believe that the caregivers' overload and stress, as well as the pandemic situation has affected not only the completion of the reminiscence therapy, but its quality when performed since caregivers did not have the time or materials available to diversify the following sessions.                           Regarding the information collected by the caregivers from each session, they register the materials that elicited positive emotional reactions (57%), materials that helped to recall past memories (55%), the emotional state of the PwD both before and after the session (38% each), and the material that elicited negative emotional reactions (19%).             There are no other types of information that caregivers would like to include in their notes about each session.             Fourteen percent of caregivers do not collect any information.                          \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Follow-up Medical Appointments                                             Thirty-seven percent of surveyed caregivers take the PwD to follow-up medical appointment, in particular they accompany the PwD on a daily (32%) or weekly (16%) basis.             Thirty-four percent of caregivers reported that the PwD do not go to follow-up appointments despite having indicated they did in the previous question.              We believe this is due to not having immediately understood the concept of follow-up appointment.             Caregivers report they do not attend the appointments more often due to lack of time.                      The emotional reactions and emotional well-being of the PwD is usually analysed during the appointments (64% each), as well as the results from previous reminiscence sessions (48%).             Additionally, caregivers perform other follow-up of PwD besides medical consultations or reminiscence therapy, such as cognitive stimulation, walks in places PwD used to enjoy, art therapy, shopping, visiting places where PwD lived, psychomotricity activities, daily contact with the PwD, and gathering relevant information through collaborators/health team.                          \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Interest in Technological Functionalities                       Thirty three percent of caregivers take advantage of technology to take care of PwD, such as audio books, blue laser light, camera, computer, Internet, phone, radio, tablet/iPad, television, and videos.                              Considering the different technological functionalities for the management and adaptation of reminiscence sessions, informal caregivers have a moderate interest for the most part (median of 3 in 5 for each).             This apparent decrease in interest (compared to our previous survey) will be addressed in the follow-up interviews.             The actual performance of the reminiscence therapy has not proved to be statistically significant for any of the functionalities in question.                              Caregivers indicate that they are comfortable introducing personal content into a technological system, as long as the system guarantees maximum privacy and security.                      \u00a7.\u00a7 Formal Caregivers               Following, we present our results regarding formal caregivers.                      \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Sample Characteristics                       A total of 34 formal caregivers answered our survey.              They were mostly female (85%), younger than 50 y-o (64%), completed higher education (85%), and do not have any visual impairments (65%).             They take care of more than seven PwD (76%), and at least one of the PwD is in a severe state of dementia (74%).                          The majority of caregivers are familiar with technology: they use mobile phones daily, and computers/tablet/iPad six days a week.                              \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Reminiscence Therapy                       Formal caregivers perform reminiscence therapy sessions more often than the informal ones (68% vs 41%).             They usually conduct the sessions 3-4 (39%) or 5-10 (30%) times per month.             Sessions occur mainly at the institution (74%) but in the house of the PwD as well (35%), with an average duration of 30-60 minutes (65%) or less than 30 minutes (30%).                          Images (95%), music (87%), videos (57%), and text (48%) are used to stimulate memories, and are both personal (87%) and general (83%).                          Caregivers would like to use video (57%), text (48%), images (43%), music (39%), and other materials (such as objects, arts' material, games, daily activities, and visits to places of interest) more often.                          The materials used are related to places where the person lived (96%), PwD's relatives (87%), places PwD visited (83%), jobs of the PwD (78%), pets (70%), and vehicles they had (43%).             Caregivers also report that they like to use material related to other topics such as habits, hobbies, favorite food, musicians, television shows, movies and actors, important dates, past and present objects, sports, or plants.             Materials are obtained through the Internet (87%), or provided by PwD's relatives (74%), the PwD (57%), or friends (43%).             The material is updated in a monthly (26%), weekly (22%), daily or fortnightly (17% each) basis.             They do not update it more often due to lack of time (100%), lack of perceived usefulness for the PwD (50%), and lack of materials or need to repeat the same activities (25% each).                              Caregivers collect information about the emotional state of the PwD after sessions (87%), material that helped to recall past memories or elicited positive emotional reactions (83% each), material that elicited negative emotional reactions (70%), PwD's emotional state before sessions (65%), and duration of each session (48%).             Moreover, they also collect the degree of involvement and interest of PwD, level of communication, dynamics with caregiver or the group, PwD answers during the session, as well as periodic assessments of cognitive functions.                          Finally, they show interest in being able to collect the intensity level of emotional reactions (positive and negative) to specific stimuli, record permission for assessments, how the PwD was during the session (refusals, non-verbal language, behavior, relationship with therapist, initiative in contact), and in-session responses that might be relevant in future sessions.                      \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Follow-up Medical Appointments                       Fifty-three percent of the formal caregivers conduct follow-up medical appointments with the PwD on a daily (28%) or weekly (28%) basis.             Caregivers report they do not conduct appointments more often because of the costs associated.                              The emotional well-being of the PwD is almost always evaluated at the appointments (93%), followed by the PwD's emotional reactions (87%), and the results from previous reminiscence sessions (67%).             Other follow-up activities with the PwD are conducted (49%), in particular, cognitive stimulation, movement sessions, sensory stimulation sessions, hygiene/food care, caregiver support with family members and joint sessions (PwD and family), psychotherapy, and games.                                \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Interest in Technological Functionalities                           Sixty-five percent of caregivers already use technology to help them in the care of the PwD, in particular, the CogWeb application <cit.>, computer, images, music, mobile phones, overhead projector, snoezelen (multi sensory) room, tablet, and videos.                          They are interested in all the technological functionalities, in particular, they are very interested in those related to the adaptation and personalization of sessions.             Their interest is much higher than that of the informal caregivers, which we believe is due to the fact that most of the informal caregivers only take care of one person and do not need to manage several PwD at the same time.             Such difference in the interest across the type of caregivers is statistically significant for all functionalities:                          Management of PwD:         \t             \t   \t       * Creating reminders ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t   \t       * Notifying other caregivers ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t   \t       * Sharing care with others ( RPLUS MATCH )                          \tReminiscence sessions:         \t             \t           * Automatically adapting the session content based on the biographical information of the PwD ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Automatically adapting the session content based on the emotional reactions of the PwD to the materials presented ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Consulting the materials used in each therapy session ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Consulting the history of caregiver's sessions ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Consulting the history of the PwD's sessions even if performed by others ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t             \t            \tMaterial used in the therapy sessions:         \t             \t           * Inserting new material ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Inserting material topics ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Creating a favorites section in each patient's material ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t                 Help tools for the users:         \t             \t           * Email/Telephone ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Help within application ( RPLUS MATCH )         \t           * Instructions manual (U=1231.00, p=.010", "statisticType": "mwutest", "record": {"pval": ".010", "U": "1231.00", "r": null, "z": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

disease ( RPLUS MATCH ).              \tPost-hoc analysis reveals a statistically significant difference between mild and severe stages (p=.002), with caregivers of PwD in a severe stage being more percent of the PwD are performing reminiscence therapy, while 23% stopped doing it due to increased detachment of the PwD (66%), lack of perceived usefulness or PwD inability to attend sessions (25%), from 39 countries worldwide answered the survey.     \t    Fifty-eight duplicate responses were removed.     \t         \t        \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Informal Caregivers       \t             \t    Ninety two percent of the respondents are female, younger than 60 y-o (74%), completed higher education (70%), have mild to moderate visual impairments (54%), are currently unemployed (43%), and are
